article.description:
The Orlando Magic improved 2-0 for the first time
since 1993, taking advantage of Miami's sputtering offense and
defensive breakdowns to spoil the Heat's season opener, 100-86
Wednesday night.
article.headline: Magic start season 2-0 for first time since 1993
article.linkText: Magic's 1-2 punch of McGrady and Hill doom Heat
article.story:
MIAMI (AP) -- The NBA season has started just the way the Orlando Magic hoped, and just the way the Miami Heat feared.
Hill

McGrady

Orlando, expected to contend for the Atlantic Division title, improved 2-0 for the first time since 1993 by spoiling the Heat's season opener Wednesday, 100-86. Miami looked like a team rebuilding in the absence of All-Star center Alonzo Mourning, who watched from a private suite. A sputtering offense and defensive breakdowns doomed the Heat after they raced to an early eight-point lead. Tracy McGrady scored 24 points and Grant Hill added 17 for the Magic, who used the same 1-2 punch to beat Philadelphia in their opener Tuesday. "Grant and Tracy are playing so well off of one another, it's scary,'' coach Doc Rivers said. "It was pretty interesting to watch the two interact. It's amazing when you can tag-team your opponent like that.'' The Magic shot 65 percent in the first half as they built a 54-45 lead. They finished at 55 percent, including 8-for-12 from 3-point range. "People don't usually score 100 points on us,'' Heat guard Eddie Jones said. "We felt we should have given a better effort defensively.'' Coach Pat Riley used stronger language regarding his defense. "Horrendous,'' he said. "They were making straight-line drives to the basket. Our perimeter guys did not contain the ball.'' Travis Best and rookie Caron Butler made impressive debuts for Miami. Offseason free-agent acquisition Best shot 8-for-13 and scored 22 points, his highest total in two seasons. Butler, the first lottery draft pick of Riley's career, had 16 points and seven rebounds, including a highlight-reel one-handed rebound and dunk. "That even lifted me out of my seat,'' Riley said. "I had a solid game,'' Butler said. "But we lost, so it doesn't matter.'' Malik Allen added 22 points and seven rebounds in just his 13th NBA game. But two veteran holdovers, Jones and Brian Grant, scored just six points apiece. Grant moved from forward to the starting center spot in place of Mourning, who is sidelined again by a kidney ailment that will likely force him to miss the entire season. Anthony Carter, who was slated to start at point guard for Miami, stayed home with strep throat. Best started instead and had 12 points and three assists in the first 10 minutes, helping Miami to a 32-24 lead early in the second quarter. Orlando went ahead to stay 2½ minutes later. McGrady slashed to the basket for a dunk, then hit a 3-pointer on the next possession to put the Magic up 35-34. McGrady and Hill shot a combined 15-for-23. "Basically it's our show,'' McGrady said. "The ball winds up in our hands 90 percent of the time, but the other guys have roles, too.'' Orlando put the game away by scoring 12 consecutive points midway through the second half for a 90-69 lead. Pat Garrity had 16 points and Mike Miller 14 for the Magic. Each sank three 3-pointers, and the Magic bench outscored Miami's 44-14. Orlando had lost three in a row against the Heat and 15 of the past 20 regular-season meetings. The Magic won at Miami for only the second time in their past eight tries. Rivers wasn't inclined to get carried away by Orlando's first 2-0 start in nine years. "I don't know if that's a great stat or not,'' he said. Game notes
Magic forward Horace Grant (sore left knee) did not dress. ... Mourning, who was not around the team during the preseason, declined to talk with reporters. "He's tortured by this whole thing,'' Riley said of Mourning's illness. "He's showing a lot of respect because he doesn't want to continue to be the story. He has done enough talking about it. He just wants to be left alone, and let him work on it and get healthy.'' ... Six of the Heat's first seven games are at home. Last year they went 18-23 at home. "That was our biggest downfall,'' Riley said. ... Jones lost a season opener for the first time. He had been 7-0, the best record among active players in the NBA. ... McGrady averaged 25.7 points against the Heat last season.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
